Mechanism: Formation of a two-dimensional electron gas (2DEG) at the heterojunction interface -> Electron confinement -> Enhanced mobility
Polycrystalline IGO layer -> Superior carrier percolation conduction paths -> High mobility
H2 addition during sputtering -> Reduced crystal nucleation density -> Larger grains -> Less susceptible to grain boundary scattering -> High mobility
Sn-doping -> Large dispersion of the conduction band composed of Sn5s orbitals -> High mobility
Pulse-induced Joule heating -> Induces quasi-two-dimensional electron gas (q-2DEG) at IZO/IGZO interface -> Mitigates electron scattering and strengthens carrier confinement -> Improves mobility

Pd electrode as hydrogen transfer pathway -> Catalytic dissociation of H2 into atomic H -> H reacts with interface oxide -> Forms highly conductive metallized interlayer -> Reduced contact resistance and increased mobility

a-IGZO/In-rich a-IGZO heterostructure -> Quantum confinement effect confines carrier path to heterointerface -> Carrier path is shifted away from gate insulator -> Reduced interface trap density and enhanced transport -> High mobility and stability
IZO layer forms 2DEG at interface with IGZO:Hf -> Accumulates free carriers -> Improves mobility. Hf doping -> Reduces oxygen vacancies (Vo) -> Improves stability.
Engineered Al2O3/HfO2 dual-layer gate insulator -> Controlled hydrogen diffusion and mitigated electron traps at the IGZO/GI interface -> Enhanced PBTS stability and excellent electrical performance.
Al2O3 passivation layer -> Suppression of channel defects (Oxygen Vacancies, Hydroxyls) and increased metal-oxide bonding -> Improved carrier transport and device stability.
Bilayer IGZO/ITZO structure -> Optimization of shallow donor defect density -> Simultaneous achievement of high mobility and less negative Vth.
Bilayer channel with oxygen-compensated capping layer -> Increased metal oxide concentration and decreased oxygen vacancy and hydroxyl concentration -> Enhanced mobility and bias stability.
Interfacial oxidation of Ta gate metal during annealing -> Formation of a very thin (15 nm) TaOx gate insulator -> Enables low voltage operation (< 1V).
Dual-active-layer architecture -> Accumulation of high carrier concentration at the interface between the gate dielectric and the front-channel layer -> High mobility.

IZO homojunction + CF4 plasma treatment + Al2O3 passivation -> q-2DEG formation + fluorine doping of back channel + reduction of deep-subgap state density -> High mobility and superior gate-bias stress stability.
Dual-gate, multi-channel (IGZTO/IZO) structure -> Formation of 2D electron gas (2DEG) at hetero-interface and three-channel conduction -> High mobility and excellent PBTS stability.
Hydrogen doping from PEALD SiO2 passivation into Sn-containing IGZO (IGZTO) -> Formation of substitutional H on O sites (Ho), which reduces effective mass -> Boosted carrier mobility and stability.
Multichannel IGZO:Hf/IZO/IGZO:Hf structure -> 2DEG formation at hetero-interface and suppression of oxygen vacancies by Hf doping -> High mobility and high stability.

Oxygen Compensated Capping Layer (CCL) deposition -> Diffusion of compensated oxygen from CCL to Uncompensated Channel Layer (UCL) during annealing -> Increased Metal-Oxide concentration and decreased Oxygen Vacancy (Vo) and -OH concentration -> Enhanced mobility and stability.

Engineered Al2O3/HfO2 dual-layer gate insulator -> Precise modulation of Hydrogen (H) diffusion and electron trapping dynamics -> Balances Vth control, SS, and interface quality -> Maintains high mobility while improving stability over single-layer insulators.
Polycrystalline IGO front channel combined with IGZO back channel -> Heterojunction structure induces energy band bending -> Accumulation of free carriers at the IGO/IGZO interface -> High mobility.

Optimal O2/(Ar+O2) ratio of 2% -> Suppresses carrier concentration from conductive state without over-oxidizing -> Balances carrier density and reduces weakly bonded oxygen -> High mobility and improved stability.

Short O2 plasma time (0.3s) during PEALD of SiO2 gate insulator -> Incomplete reaction of precursors -> Higher H incorporation and higher Oxygen Vacancy (Vo) in Al:ITZO channel -> High carrier concentration -> High mobility.
Pristine (undoped) In2O3 -> High concentration of native oxygen vacancies -> High intrinsic carrier density -> High mobility.

Hf in HIZO back-channel -> Adsorbs oxygen ions from IZO front-channel during annealing -> Creates a vertically graded oxygen vacancy profile (low Vo in back, high Vo in front) -> High mobility from front channel and high stability from back channel.
Ga doping -> Promotes M-O bonding and reduces oxygen-related defects (Vo) -> Suppresses excessive carriers and reduces defect states -> High mobility and stability
No mechanism info.
Dual-gate operation -> Quantum mechanical channel formation in center of active layer -> Reduced parasitic resistance -> Higher mobility
High-temperature anneal + YOx capping layer -> Promotes crystallization and suppresses excess free electrons -> Reduces bulk trap states (In-disorder, imperfect M-O bonding) -> Enhanced stability
ITZO/IGZO heterojunction + Al2O3 passivation -> 2DEG formation + suppression of Vo and -OH defects -> High carrier concentration and reduced traps -> High mobility and excellent stability

Optimized GZO layer on IGZO -> Minimized interface defect density + band alignment modulation -> Reduced electron trapping and physical separation of channel from gate insulator -> High mobility and stability
CF4 plasma treatment on HfO2 gate insulator -> Fluorine passivates oxygen vacancies at the IGZO/HfO2 interface -> Reduced electron trapping sites -> Enhanced mobility and stability
Longer channel length -> Reduced relative impact of source/drain parasitic resistance -> Higher extracted field-effect mobility
a-IGZTO/a-IZO heterojunction with Dual Gate -> Formation of 2DEG and three conduction channels -> High carrier concentration and transport paths -> High mobility and excellent PBTS stability
N2O plasma with Al2O3 protective layer -> Passivates oxygen vacancies in IGZO bulk without creating interface traps -> Reduced trap density -> Significantly enhanced stability
DUV/Thermal Dual Treatment (DTT) -> Generation of oxygen radicals (O*) -> Promotes M-O bond formation and reduces defects/interface traps -> High mobility and improved stability
Post-deposition annealing (500 C) -> Reduction in oxygen vacancies and sub-gap defect states -> Decreased electron density and trap states -> Positive Vth shift, improved SS, and enhanced mobility

Optimal Sb doping (3%) -> Maximizes Sb5+ ratio -> Sb5+ acts as donor (increases carriers) and oxygen binder (suppresses Vo, strengthens M-O bonds) -> Optimized charge transport path and reduced trap states -> High mobility and stability
Optimal In:Zn ratio (43:57) -> Lowest oxygen deficiency (O-de) ratio and minimal bulk/interface defects -> Highest stability (lowest PBTS shift) and good mobility
Ti doping -> Strong Ti-O bond formation -> Suppresses oxygen vacancy (Vo) formation -> Reduced carrier concentration and improved NBS stability -> Trade-off between mobility and stability

a-IGZTO/a-IZO heterostructure -> Conduction band offset (ΔEc ≈ 0.22 eV) -> Formation of 2D Electron Gas (2DEG) at interface -> High carrier concentration and multiple conduction paths -> High mobility and robust PBTS stability

Thermal annealing (250 C in air) -> Oxygen incorporation and structural relaxation -> Reduced oxygen vacancies (Vo) and increased M-O bonds -> Defect passivation and improved interface quality -> Enhanced mobility, positive Vth shift, and improved stability

Low-temp activation (200 C) with MgOx layer -> Mg atoms diffuse into IGZO channel -> Forms Mg-doped IGZO (MIGZO) with strong Mg-O bonds -> Suppresses oxygen vacancies and reduces defects at low temperature -> Enhanced mobility and stability

Moderate In doping (3%) -> In acts as Vo suppressor AND In's larger 5s orbitals increase orbital overlap -> Reduced carrier concentration (positive Vth shift) and enhanced percolation pathways -> Optimal balance of high mobility and good stability
Deposition in obstacle shadow -> Higher oxygen incorporation in film -> Lower concentration of oxygen vacancies -> Higher resistivity channel suitable for transistor operation
Polycrystalline IGO layer -> Superior carrier percolation conduction paths -> High mobility. Stacked structure also induces carrier accumulation at the heterojunction interface.
Post-deposition annealing -> Reduction in oxygen vacancies and sub-gap defect states -> Positive Vth shift and enhanced mobility
Air annealing -> Oxygen incorporation -> Reduction in Vo from 26% to 20.6% -> Defect passivation and transition from depletion to enhancement mode
IGTO/IGZO heterojunction -> Large conduction band shift -> Generation of two-dimensional electron gas at the interface -> High mobility
Hf doping -> Suppresses excess charge carriers -> Optimal balance between mobility and carrier concentration for FET operation
Hybrid Microwave Annealing (h-MWA) -> Rapid, uniform volumetric heating -> Efficient defect passivation and reduction of oxygen-related defects -> Enhanced mobility and stability
Nitrogen High-Pressure Annealing (HPA) -> Structural relaxation -> Increased carrier concentration, decreased deep-level defects and oxygen vacancies -> Improved mobility and stability

Ozone (O3) annealing at 75°C -> O3 decomposition into atomic oxygen -> Passivation of interface defects (dangling bonds) and reduction of bulk oxygen vacancies -> Reduced Subthreshold Swing (SS) and improved stability

Solid-State Laser Annealing (SLA) -> Breaks weak metal-oxide bonds to form oxygen vacancies (Vo) and induces film densification -> Increased carrier concentration and improved carrier pathway -> Enables transistor switching

High-Pressure H2O Post-Annealing (H2O HPPA) -> Oxygen and Hydrogen penetrate film -> Passivation of metal ions, oxygen vacancies, and M-OH bonds -> Reduced interface trap states -> Improved uniformity and stability
Atomic Layer Deposition (ALD) using H2O -> Formation of dense, high-quality In2O3 film with low impurities -> Superior orbital overlap and low scattering -> High mobility
Wet process damage (PR/Stripper) -> O3 Annealing + UV irradiation -> Removes organic contamination and repairs surface O-related defects (Vo, Oi) -> Restored electrical performance and reliability
ALD Supercycle Design ending with Zn sub-cycles -> Creates a Zn-rich back channel surface -> Suppresses formation of parasitic back channel and adsorption of O2/H2O -> Improved PBTS stability

UV/O3 treatment + 300°C anneal on GaZrOx dielectric -> Smoother dielectric surface, higher M-O content, lower Vo and -OH defects -> Reduced trap states at dielectric/channel interface -> High mobility and stability

Ar Plasma Treatment -> Creates oxygen vacancies and initial defects -> Subsequent Thermal Annealing -> Enhanced atomic mobility allows effective reconfiguration of M-O bonds -> Improved mobility and stability at a lower annealing temperature
Oxygen Plasma Treatment (40W, 90s) -> Fills oxygen vacancies (Vo) in SnOx film -> Reduces carrier concentration and improves film quality -> High mobility achieved with high-k Al2O3 dielectric

Post-metallization annealing in air -> Repairs oxygen vacancies created at metal/semiconductor interface during contact deposition -> Reduces mobile electron density and trap states -> Improved uniformity, positive Vth shift, and low SS
CF4 plasma treatment -> Incorporation of F dopants bonds with metal ions and passivates interfacial traps and vacancy states -> Reduced defect states -> Improved mobility and bias stability
Focused N2 plasma treatment -> Reduces oxygen vacancies (Ovac) and metal-hydroxyl (M-OH) groups -> Lowers trap site density -> Improved mobility and stability
Higher ALD growth temperature (200°C) -> Increased oxygen deficiency and shallow donor states -> Higher carrier concentration and Hall mobility -> High performance and improved PBTS stability
Low-temperature (150°C) ALD -> High-density, high-quality polycrystalline film -> Good mobility and stability. Ohmic contact from Ti scavenging oxygen.

Argon plasma treatment -> Induces film densification and increases nonstoichiometric oxygen (Vo) -> Higher mobile carrier concentration and lower interface trap density -> Enhanced mobility and stability
Low-Temperature Deuterium Annealing (LTDA) -> Deuterium passivates interface traps (Dit) -> Reduced trap density -> Improved mobility, SS, and hot-carrier reliability
No mechanism info.
Polycrystalline IGO layer and heterojunction -> Carrier accumulation at interface -> High Mobility; Lower oxygen vacancy concentration -> fewer trap states -> better stability
Deposition at 150C -> local disorder decrease -> increased intrinsic mobility
Paper focuses on modeling DOS from electrical characteristics, not the physical origin of performance.
null
Use of high capacitive dielectrics (Al2O3) -> mitigates interface trap effects -> steep subthreshold swing
Bilayer structure (IZO for mobility, HIZO for stability) -> IZO provides high mobility path, Hf in HIZO suppresses oxygen vacancy formation -> High mobility with good stability
Hydrogen annealing -> Termination of subgap defects and electron trap sites -> Reduced subgap DOS and high mobility
Polycrystalline IGO layer -> Carrier accumulation at hetero-interface and fewer oxygen vacancies -> High mobility and better stability
Not Applicable (Modeling Thesis)
Gradient in crystallinity and Al concentration -> Low-resistance path for carrier transport without traditional channel formation -> Ultra-high mobility
